Forking this idea, since I think it's worth its own thread:

Ken Clary said:

that's similar to my earlier suggestion, of something like "reply (general/onboarding)." maybe if we are very explicit, it'll be less confusing.

I think this idea would actually be pretty helpful! Especially if we style things cleverly.

I could even imagine a design for that bottom row that look like this:

general > onboarding [ wide text box ] [New topic] [New private message]

with the "wide text box" thing would be a textarea that it's actually impossible to enter, because when you click it, it just opens the compose box for a reply. This would eliminate the confusion of "there's no textbox at the bottom" -- because there would be one -- while preserving our structure that the compose box is a more-than-one-line object that makes it convenient to write paragraphs and the like.
Or maybe we just have "Reply to general > onboarding" as the placeholder inside the text box, rather than having it outside?
I prefer buttons to fake text boxes. Some kind of icon that suggest composing might draw attention to the button.
image.png
(As a super hacky 1-minute prototype)
It’s definitely worth an experiment

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I prefer buttons to fake text boxes. Some kind of icon that suggest composing might draw attention to the button.

A large portion of complaints from new users, both in feedback and in usability study settings, is "I can't figure out how to send a message" -- because they're trained from every other chat too to look for a text box at the bottom of the screen that they can click into to reply. This approach provides one.

I think the main thing that might go wrong with this plan is the question would become "why is the keyboard focus not in that text box", but that's a smaller problem since new users will almost certainly start with the mouse.
I like that quite alot
Another thing we can do with this is change the placeholder text to "Saved as draft!" when we close the compose box to save a draft -- which would potentially be a cleaner fix to zulip/zulip#17396.
also, textbox or no, I like putting reply left-most.

Ken Clary said:

also, textbox or no, I like putting reply left-most.

We've been through like 5 iterations on where the buttons are (left/right justified, etc.) with the goal of fixing the problem of "how do I send a message". And the structural problem with them all is that new users find them invisible because they're looking for a textbox. I think the last iteration thought putting "Reply" last would help, which is why it's there.
I'll note that in your mockup, the implied stream/topic for reply does not match the highlighted message.
Yeah, that's because I did my mockup in a development environment and wanted to use the stream name from here -- please ignore that discrepancy in my 1-minute mockup :smile:
np
I also like it being a small textbox, ultimately acting like a button.
We should try this out. Apart from feeling a bit strange, I don’t see any downside for long term users.

I think there's enough interest in this direction that we should make an issue for someone to implement it -- we can then test-deploy it to chat.zulip.org and play with it for a few days and see what we thing.

It'd end up working like search boxes in some sites (where it's too small to type anything, but expands to consume other UI widgets' space on click).
OK I'll do an issue writeup.
Our search box should actually do this, instead of the unintuitive thing we have now.
Tagging as a release goal. @Ken Clary would you be interested in prototyping this, since you were looking for a first project?

note: "closed compose box" is a bit of a misnomer. it's a button, with a dynamic label, that opens the compose box.

Yeah, by this I meant "the state of the compose area when the compose box is closed".

The real test of whether this change is successful is whether it can help users who are looking for a way to reply at the bottom of the message feed -- if anyone has a roommate who you can have try joining chat.zulip.org and just watch over their shoulder as a mini usability study, that'd be a helpful test of whether this design is successful.
(The other question is whether existing users find it distracting/confusing).

One other thought: We could considering putting in the button label the keyboard shortcut (Enter) with our standard lighter styling to help teach that as well. The main downside of that is risk of creating a feeling of clutter.
Also, one nice touch I've noticed with this PR is that if you're in an interleaved view and move through messages with the arrow keys, the button label makes clear where a reply would go.

"Message #stream > topic"
"Reply to #stream > topic"

I don't think that accurately explains why the Reply button was invisible. Besides placement and prominence (size), "Reply" as a word is a confusing/misleading verb for what's happening.
I agree with "Message"; I think if we do fancier styling, we might want something that involves using the stream color rather than something like italics. (But I think it's better to be plain-text).
(see also my suggestion of things like "broadcast")
(Oh, I guess the original proposal was italics, not bold. Oops. Perils of a terminal client.)
bold looks too distracting to my eyes, but italics is a little ugly. stream color could be nice, if it remains readable. or a generic highlight color.

Perhaps just doing this "open compose box" decoration at the right end of the button could work.

image.png
Plain seems fine, yeah. (Really any of the four seem fine.)
also/instead, coloring the whole button green, like the "Send" button
Oh, hm, one theory is "everyone is looking for a different verb, so since we have a "New message" button, the 'compose box' should use reply"
though that might feel weird if "New topic" and "New private message" aren't also green

In the email paradigm, "reply" means reply to one person, "reply all" means reply to the whole thread. Yet, adding in the dynamic label (e.g. so in interleaved mode, you know where you're replying), the verb matters less, as long as it's clear.
"Message" is what's used in the compose placeholder, so there's some consistency there
even if "message" as a verb is kinda nuevo

Tim Abbott said:

Perhaps just doing this "open compose box" decoration at the right end of the button could work.

this seems unlikely to be meaningful to new users

broadly speaking, putting the button leftmost, and stretching it out to fill as much space as possible, puts the-thing-they-are-looking-for in the-place-they-are-looking. Labeling it "Reply to #stream > topic" or even just "<verb> #stream > topic" does a much better job at advertising what the button does, and (maybe, hopefully) teaches them something about how topics, narrows, and interleaved modes work.
if it were just a text box (like, fully opened compose box, or smaller-version-that-expands-when-focused), it would fit their pre-existing expectations about how chat forums work (going back to AIM? older?). But if it's a button that kinda-sorta looks like a text box, but doesn't behave like one, I think it'll just be more cognitive dissonance.

I didn't follow the discussion, but I noticed the current bottom row design here and I think it's really cool! :thumbs_up:

Definitely not! And we probably want to think about changing the "Saved as draft" behavior with this new feature anyway.
I think the button should say the same thing as the compose box does when it's opened up; "Message #stream > topic" is my preference, but I care more about consistency.
For having the back and forth feel smooth, I'd also be inclined to use the same text formatting, e.g. matching the faded color we use for suggestions.

Robert (ro-i) said:

One tiny issue: While the green notification "saved as draft" appears (when you write a message and cancel it using Esc), the "Drafts" button moves a few pixels up. Is this intended?

This looks like a padding interaction that now crops up due to the use of flexbox (not entirely certain of that, however). Anyway, I have a local fix for it. Though I agree that the "saved" notification feature should probably be redesigned with this change.

@Ken Clary would you be up for adding a separate commit to your PR that switches to placeholder-color styling? I think it's probably worth trying that here for a day to see how folks feel about that alternative.

Tim Abbott said:

Ken Clary would you be up for adding a separate commit to your PR that switches to placeholder-color styling? I think it's probably worth trying that here for a day to see how folks feel about that alternative.

Yes, though that will be tomorrow. (also, longer thoughts incoming)

This is, somewhat, an aside:

html placeholder texts have some known accessibility issues. (Collected in various places; see https://www.deque.com/blog/accessible-forms-the-problem-with-placeholders/ for some examples.) The most relevant issue here is the (intentional, to denote "this is a hint") lower contrast/visibility. In particular, mimicing that style for button text seems very unwise. From some perspectives, this could be a very important button; making its label harder to read would be a problem.

(Relatedly, in order to match the placeholder style, I'll need to reverse engineer the browser default, I think, and it might shift by browser. We could solve that by making a .placeholder style, I suppose. Note that, if we were to also use that to increase contrast, it would likely defeat the purpose of placeholders in input in the first place.)

However, all this only coincidentally dovetails with my primary objection. I think that decorating a button to mimic an input (lower contrast text or not) is deceptive UX. I don't think it'll be a magic bullet for onboarding, but even if it were, it still feels like a hack. Either it's a button, and should look and behave like a button, or we should use an actual input field that looks and behaves like an input field --- and, probably, also consider redesigning the compose box to be more compact as to be left open all the time. (Personally, I think the button route will have better results, but there are many design considerations here, and I'm very new to this side of this project ;)

My two cents is that we should try to make it look more like a button now. I find the super-long button to be kind of awkward and distracting while I'm reading. My subconscious is busy trying to process what that thing is--is it a button? why is it so long? it almost looks like a compose box, or even another message, but it's not? Meanwhile the other buttons are easy to tune out. (I've tried to wait a day for this feedback, as I am obviously used to the old UI.)
any thoughts on how to make it more button-like? give it a color? thicker borders? 3d look?

My main thought is just not make it so long. But I have always thought a simple border effect (like color, not too thick, but easy to notice) would go a long way here:

  • newbies would see it
  • oldies would tune it out quickly if they just want to read the messages (since it looks like a button and not some other text element)

I'm probably in the minority here, but I find that my eye goes down the lower right to find the actionable button, not the left, so I'd want this on the right for newbies (similar to how Send is to the right when you open the compose box).

[Drafts] [New topic] [New PM]                       [Message #foo > bar>]

So I've test-deployed the revised "more button like" version here so folks can experience it.

My main worry with these ideas that are focused on making a "want to click" button is that it makes this button pretty distracting for a long-term user who's learned to use Zulip via the keyboard and will never click this button.

This is kinda a subtle UI problem, in that we want to make this button draw attention for new users, but also not be a thing that long-term users need to find. Which is very different from Amazon's buy buttons, for example.

I think (today), the focus has been on making it look less-like-part-of-the-message-feed, rather than want-to-click. I don't think it should be more want-to-click than the other buttons, but it should be more intuitive to find, among them.

Personally, my immediate reaction is "Ahh, this button is giant and green!". I felt the bland button approach we had in the initial prototype felt a lot more ignorable.

If a lot of other folks have that reaction (especially if they didn't have it yesterday), this highlighted button direction is probably not a good one (because that means we'll get like a million emails complaining about this change if we try to ship it).

I think it's easier for an advanced user to tune out a button that actually looks like a button (even with some embellishment) than something that just either looks odd or looks like it's part of the message feed.

(agreed it's a tricky problem)
the sea-green is just a snapshot, anyway

I know I'm not exactly the target audience for this change, but the recently deployed changes are much easier on my eyes. (I'm in day mode, and the color is both noticeable and subtle enough to tune out.)

One anomaly that I've noticed since this change is that I'm more likely to accidentally hit escape to "dismiss" the compose box, when actually the compose box isn't even open. Which jumps me to Recent Topics. I am wondering if anybody else has noticed that.

OK, I went ahead and merged this; I think any changes we're likely to consider in the future are little color tweaks, and the current version feels good enough to be a clear improvement to master.

We should get some feedback when this makes it out to Zulip Cloud later this week; if that suggests we should change the design details, we can reopen the conversation.
(At least for me personally, the current design threads the needing we had of not being distracting).
I guess one quirk I want to highlight is the little "Saved as draft" notice that we display when closing the compose box looks a little weird following this.
I kinda feel like that's an independent thing we want to fix -- that notice has its own issues of being semi-invisible beforehand.
yeah, there are a number of approaches for that, so it makes sense for a separate issue

I guess the final question I have is whether we feel this lets us remove the first "whale" hotspots notice about how to reply to a message? There's still some utility in teaching that clicking on a message triggers a reply, but the button is a least there for folks who don't try that.
What folks' thougts on what do with the "Saved as draft" notice? It definitely looks pretty funky right now.

my "first pass" would be to have the Drafts button itself change labels, to "Saved" in seagreen or whatever. however, having that work without dynamically switching the button width could be tricky (and language-dependent)

I don't understand why the "make it look like a text box" idea was dropped? I think Tim Abbotts argument that it'll help new users find what they're looking for pretty solid.

I don't think the "a button should look like a button" argument holds, as it's width and left alignment already makes it very un-buttonly. I didn't realize it was a button when I first saw it.

If styling it like a text field, I think new users will quickly realize that it's a "special button" and get used to that after discovering that it pops up a bigger text area.
I guess we never test-deployed here a version for testing with the placeholder-style design; maybe that's worth trying out via a test-deploy here.

@Thomas Fini Hansen thanks for the feedback! I don't think we heard the feedback that some users thought the current design was a disabled text box from this community; we certainly don't want that perception.
OK I'm test-deploying here an alternative styling that makes the button look more like a placeholder.

I think I agree that philosophically, the role of this element is to be a thing you click on in order to compose a messages, which is the same thing an empty text box with a placeholder does. So I don't we would be tricking the user in a way that they'll be upset about by making it appear similarly to the textarea that the user is looking for and expects given the wide size of the widget.
I still firmly believe that is deceptive UX and a bad idea. (also, "placeholder" is definitionally harder to read, and otherwise a problem with text boxes themselves...)

That's the terminology we've used for that concept for a long time, and I think it's probably more intuitive than "highlighted", since the blue box is only arguably a highlight, but it's definitely a selection.

I guess summing up my thinking:

  • If you're hovering over the button, it's because you want more information about what it does -- not just a repeat of the button's label.
  • The "Message foo > bar" content of the button already cleanly expresses what the button will do if you click it right now.
  • The hover text "Reply to selected message (r)" explains to you what that button's role is in all situations, not just with the current selection, and thus documents the concept. And it also gives you clarify if you're thinking "but how do I reply to something in Zulip?" and try hovering over the buttons at the bottom to find out.
